Vehicle designed and constructed for the carriage of passengers and comprising no more than eight seats in addition to the driver's seat.
These vehicles have an engine cylinder capacity that

>does not exceed 50cm³

(in the case of thermic engines), and a maximum design speed that

>does not exceed 50 kilometres per hour

. For example, an electric bicycle.
These vehicles have an engine cylinder capacity that

>exceeds 50cm³

(in the case of thermic engines), or have a maximum design speed that

>exceeds 50 kilometres per hour

. For example, a motorcycle.
These vehicles have

>wheels in any arrangement

, an engine cylinder capacity that

>does not exceed 50cm³

(in the case of thermic engines), and a maximum design speed that

>does not exceed 50 kilometres per hour

. For example, an auto rickshaw.
These vehicles have

>wheels asymmetrically arranged

in relation to the longitudinal median plane, an engine cylinder capacity that

>exceeds 50cm³

(in the case of thermic engines), or have a maximum design speed that

>exceeds 50 kilometres per hour

. For example, a motorcycle with a sidecar.
These vehicles have

>wheels symmetrically arranged

in relation to the longitudinal median plane, an engine cylinder capacity that

>exceeds 50cm³

(in the case of thermic engines), or have a maximum design speed that

>exceeds 50 kilometres per hour

. For example, a motorised tricycle.
These vehicles have an unladen mass that is

>not more than 350kg

(not including the mass of the batteries in the case of electric vehicles). For vehicles with electric engines, the maximum continuous rated power

>does not exceed 4kW

. For example, a golf cart or mobility scooter.
These vehicles have an unladen mass that is

>not more than 400kg or 550kg

for vehicles intended for carrying goods (not including the mass of batteries in the case of electric vehicles). For vehicles with electric engines, the maximum continuous rated power

>does not exceed 15kW

. For example, microcars.
